newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Ok Tedi prepared for mill throughput reduction.
newsitem.headline: Ok Tedi prepared for mill throughput reduction.

text.p: The management of the giant Ok Tedi copper mine in the western highlands of Papua New Guinea said on Friday that it had made contingency plans to reduce mill throughput from about June 12 if dry weather patterns continued.
The company has already said that the unseasonal lack of rainfall had stopped the movement of concentrate barges down the Fly River.

"OTML management is making contingency plans to reduce mill throughput from approximately 12 June if nothing changes," it said. "Mining operations will be able to continue, concentrating on waste removal."

The company said the unseasonal dry weather showed no signs of changing, with meteorological reports suggesting that an El Nino (drought pattern) event was underway. This reduced the short term chances of receiving the heavy rains that usually fall at this time of year.

Ok Tedi said there were 140,000 tonnes of copper concentrate stockpiled at the mine and the port of Kiunga, while the silo ship Karabi in Port Moresby Harbour was not holding any stocks. The specially built shallow draft ships which ply the river can carry 2,500 tonnes of concentrate.
The company said it shipped about 50,000 tonnes of concentrate each month.
Ok Tedi is 52.6 percent owned by Australia's Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd, with Canada's Inmet Mining Corp owning 17.4 percent and the rest held by the Papua New Guinea government.
Dry weather in other parts on PNG earlier this week forced the Porgera gold mine to suspend mill throughput as well.
